p:
Criminalisation creates a significant barrier to harm reduction service access among women who use drugs in Europe, by dissuading service engagement for fear of exposure and by providing police with an incentive and opportunity to obstruct harm reduction behaviours. The harsh policing associated with criminalisation can diminish the agency of people who use drugs to manage their drug use and reduce harm [ 64]. The impact of criminalisation on barriers to harm reduction services for women who use drugs can be broken into three interconnected phenomena:
formal, legal barriers that obstruct access for women who use drugs;
interactions with law enforcement agencies that reduce the ability or willingness of women to access services; and
the incarceration of women who use drugs.
